awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Resolving Novel Arctic Late Season Phytoplankton Blooms
awd_abstract_narration:
Warming temperatures and decreased sea ice cover in the Pacific and Central Arctic have led to changes in annual growth patterns of marine algae (phytoplankton), most notably permitting novel growth to occur during the fall season. Phytoplankton serve as the foundation of the Arctic marine food web, and disruptions in the timing of growth can be detrimental to current ecosystems. Limitations of satellite remote sensing such as the inability to detect phytoplankton bloom activity throughout the water column, under ice, and in cloudy conditions dictate the need for shipboard based measurements to provide more information on bloom dynamics. This project refines a novel methodology to estimate the growing stage of phytoplankton blooms throughout the water column using satellite imagery as a reference. Estimated summer bloom stages will be used along with atmospheric and oceanic conditions to identify the drivers of fall phytoplankton blooms to better estimate where they might occur. This information will be beneficial for predicting late season biological hotspots for conservation, scientific, and marine subsistence impacts.

Repeat cruise measurements will be used to map modeled bloom stages throughout the water column in the summer and fall throughout the Pacific Arctic and northward to the ice edge. This research will also develop two models to (1) identify immediate drivers of observed late bloom growth and (2) identify midsummer preconditioning scenarios for fall blooms and validate model predictions with in situ observations. This research utilizes two NSF-funded cruises: the Distributed Biological Observatory in July 2013–2022 and the Synoptic Arctic Survey in fall 2022. Phytoplankton chlorophyll-a and pheophytin (degraded chlorophyll) concentrations will be collected on the 2022 cruises. NASA MODIS-Aqua satellite chlorophyll-a and in situ pheophytin proportions will be used to develop bloom stage models that distinguish growing versus senescent blooms. The bloom stage model will be applied to measurements collected throughout the water column to extract more information from cruise samples, broaden the context of observations, and understand bloom progression. The fall bloom driver and preconditioning models will be developed using a machine learning regression approach. Variables that will be examined include remotely sensed and modelled datasets of high wind speed events, wind direction, sea ice breakup and freeze-up dates, and in situ measurements of nutrients, temperature, salinity, and stratification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Decreased sea ice extent has altered phytoplankton growth cycles in Arctic regions. Shifts in sea ice break up and freeze up dates have led to changes in the timing of spring phytoplankton blooms, and emerging occurrences of blooms during the fall. Major objectives of this project were to improve observations of phytoplankton growth cycles using a chlorophyll pigment index. Chlorophyll pigments (chlorophyll-a and pheophytin) were collected in marine waters of the Pacific Arctic region to estimate bloom stages based on time series of chlorophyll-a sourced from satellite remote sensing. These observations were used alongside modelled and remotely sensed observations of physical conditions to estimate region-specific drivers of fall phytoplankton blooms.

Chlorophyll-a pigments and optical casts were collected by an early career researcher aboard the U.S. Coast Guard Cutter Healy August-October 2022 to the North Pole as part of the U.S. Synoptic Arctic Survey. Pheophytin proportions of combined pheophytin and chlorophyll-a were used to observe bloom degradation into the fall season as well as provide evidence of fresh growth in late October. Building from previous work in the northern Bering Sea (Gaffey et al. 2022), these findings support that pheophytin proportions are a useful tool in estimating bloom maturity in the Pacific Arctic region, even for low chlorophyll-a concentrations. Fresh bloom signals in the fall (20-22 October 2022) may have implications on extending ecosystem activity further into the fall months which could lead to increased occupancy duration of seasonal species in Arctic regions.

The sampled phytoplankton blooms were found to absorb irradiance and increase heating rates at the vertical location of subsurface blooms while shading deeper depths from irradiance. In fact, the optical profiles collected in the Pacific Arctic region during the fall season associated each 1 μg/L increase of chlorophyll-a at the maximum with an approximate 12% decrease in heating rate within the 10 meters below the chlorophyll-a maximum depth. The finding that phytoplankton blooms trapped heat could affect stratification and potentially hinder sea ice formation depending on where blooms occur within the water column. This observation raises questions on how much heat is added in the upper water column during fall phytoplankton bloom events, and if it is enough to delay sea ice formation as a potential feedback.

For the final objective, various datasets including wind, nutrients, sea surface temperature, photosynthetic active radiation, mixed layer depth, sea ice, and summer bloom stage were analyzed as drivers for fall blooms in a machine learning Random Forests regression. Drivers varied regionally. South of St. Lawrence Island, wind direction and open water duration were the greatest predictors of fall bloom events. July pheophytin proportion was an important predictor of fall bloom events in the northern Bering and Chukchi Seas, reiterating its usefulness as an index for growing blooms. Monthly maximum wind speed was an important driver of fall blooms at sites situated in Alaskan Coastal Waters in the Chukchi Sea, but overall, these results showed that the development of fall blooms is far more nuanced than a product of wind-induced mixing.

Results of this project were disseminated to diverse audiences in several formats. Findings were presented at scientific conferences including Arctic Science Summit Week, American Geophysical Union, Ocean Sciences Meeting, and the Alaska Marine Science Symposium. Results were presented in four biology and environmental science classes at the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Massachusetts and to an Oceanography class at West Anchorage High School, the largest high school in Anchorage, Alaska. Lastly, the co-PI presented project findings during a free, public webinar as part of the Synoptic Arctic Survey webinar series.
